text: If I wanted to pool sport betting resources with friends / partners, would I need to setup a syndicate for this? Which form would it take? Are sport betting syndicates regulated by the gambling commission? I see there is a guide for <https://www.gamblingcommission.gov.uk/public-and-players/guide/running-a-lottery-syndicate|running a lottery syndicate> but I haven't found a similar page on betting syndicates. Anybody with experience in setting up a pool or with a good legal reference?

elements.text: If I wanted to pool sport betting resources with friends / partners, would I need to setup a syndicate for this? Which form would it take? Are sport betting syndicates regulated by the gambling commission? I see there is a guide for
running a lottery syndicate
but I haven't found a similar page on betting syndicates. Anybody with experience in setting up a pool or with a good legal reference?

text: What jurisdiction? I assume UK if you are referring to gambling commission

elements.text: What jurisdiction? I assume UK if you are referring to gambling commission

text: Yes, the <https://www.gamblingcommission.gov.uk/|UK Gambling Commission>.

elements.text: Yes, the
UK Gambling Commission

text: You don't need to go through any kind of formal setup procedure. The biggest question is how are you going to distribute profits? Will you have one account doing the betting or will each member have their own account?

elements.text: You don't need to go through any kind of formal setup procedure. The biggest question is how are you going to distribute profits? Will you have one account doing the betting or will each member have their own account?

text: Yes, this is part of the question. Ideally, we want to have a single account and then share from that account, i.e. pooling the bankroll (and the PnL).

elements.text: Yes, this is part of the question. Ideally, we want to have a single account and then share from that account, i.e. pooling the bankroll (and the PnL).

text: Yeah that will be a massive headache for you

elements.text: Yeah that will be a massive headache for you

text: Or does BetFair accept account application from legal entities? We would then split the compny dividends (let's be optimistic!).

text: There's no official way to set up a syndicate. You'll need to create a syndicate agreement. Up to you whether you want this checked over by a solicitor. That will be your justification for your banking activity but if the bank starts to question your transfers they will run a mile even with the syndicate agreement

elements.text: There's no official way to set up a syndicate. You'll need to create a syndicate agreement. Up to you whether you want this checked over by a solicitor. That will be your justification for your banking activity but if the bank starts to question your transfers they will run a mile even with the syndicate agreement

text:
Some advice regarding the banking situation:

1. If you can organise your betting activity such that each individual has their own betting account and earns their own betting profits this greatly simplifies matters. To distribute profits you can rotate the account being used or use all accounts simultaneously. There are bound to be some imbalances in individual profit earned but hopefully these will even out over time and require much more modest balancing payments at the end of the year
2. You _may_ have more success using an e-money provider (e.g. Revolut) rather than an actual bank (with a banking license)
3. If you do use a bank, probably better to distribute by withdrawing cash but the individuals may have problems with their own banks when depositing

elements.text: Some advice regarding the banking situation:

To distribute profits you can rotate the account being used or use all accounts simultaneously. There are bound to be some imbalances in individual profit earned but hopefully these will even out over time and require much more modest balancing payments at the end of the year
You
may
have more success using an e-money provider (e.g. Revolut) rather than an actual bank (with a banking license)
If you do use a bank, probably better to distribute by withdrawing cash but the individuals may have problems with their own banks when depositing

text: <@U0122TPQABW> - for example, my company has an actual gambling license and it is literally impossible for us to get a bank account as a legitimate bookmaker. Banks don't want to go anywhere near gambling. The risk (e..g from a money laundering perspective) far outweighs any benefits for them

text: kinda off topic of the original thread, but could someone explain pinnacles business model? Ive herd people say they can bet very large amounts without getting banned or limited, but is this true in reality?

elements.text: kinda off topic of the original thread, but could someone explain pinnacles business model? Ive herd people say they can bet very large amounts without getting banned or limited, but is this true in reality?

text: I think less true these days than before. The idea is to take a certain amount of smart money to discover the true price and then hopefully much larger volumes at small margin once that true price has been discovered

elements.text: I think less true these days than before. The idea is to take a certain amount of smart money to discover the true price and then hopefully much larger volumes at small margin once that true price has been discovered

text: To add to Mo’s on Pinnacle topic, you have the behaviour where Pinnacle shows you a maximum amount for a single bet at any given time, and if you take that max you would move their lines. And Pinnacle are very good at setting those limits and margins depending on time to event/activity/their models etc. For example, from Marco Blume’s description, they would be open to take much larger bets in the middle of a baseball season as they more confident with their models vs earlier in the season. So I’d imagine there is a combination of all these factors that they optimise and set appropriate limits and margins throughout the event lifecycle.

elements.text: To add to Mo’s on Pinnacle topic, you have the behaviour where Pinnacle shows you a maximum amount for a single bet at any given time, and if you take that max you would move their lines. So I’d imagine there is a combination of all these factors that they optimise and set appropriate limits and margins throughout the event lifecycle.
